Question_1.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the obesity-preventing effect of black ginseng extract (BGE) in the serum, liver, and hypothalamus of mice on a high-fat diet using metabolomic techniques.
Question_1.Question: What was the main finding regarding lipid metabolism in the serum of mice fed an HFD with a high concentration of BGE (BGEH)?
Question_1.Source: Lipid metabolism, including saturated fatty acids and cholesterol, was decreased in the BGEH mice.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the metabolic differences induced by black ginseng in conditions of obesity by conducting metabolic profiling of samples from the serum, liver, and hypothalamus using GC-MS.
Question_2.Question: Which metabolites were identified as important contributors in the liver of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_2.B: Decanoic acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid
Question_2.Source: Fumaric acid and citric acid, as intermediates of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, were increased in the HFD + BGEH group.

Question_3.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the obesity-preventing effect of black ginseng in the serum, liver, and hypothalamus of mice on a high-fat diet using metabolomic techniques.
Question_3.Question: What was the main finding regarding amino acids in the serum of mice fed an HFD?
Question_3.Source: Among major amino acids, alanine, leucine, isoleucine, and proline increased in the serum of HFD mice.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the metabolic differences induced by black ginseng in conditions of obesity by conducting metabolic profiling of samples from the serum, liver, and hypothalamus using GC-MS.
Question_4.Question: Which metabolites were decreased in the hypothalamus of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_4.A: Decanoic acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid
Question_4.Source: Compared to the HFD group, the HFD + BGEH group showed a decrease in eight lipids, namely decanoic acid, myristic acid, palmitic acid, stearic acid, palmitoleic acid, linoleic acid, glycerol, and cholesterol.

Question_5.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the obesity-preventing effect of black ginseng in the serum, liver, and hypothalamus of mice on a high-fat diet using metabolomic techniques.
Question_5.Question: What was the main finding regarding neurotransmission-related metabolites in the hypothalamus of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_5.B: Increased glutamic acid and fumaric acid
Question_5.Source: The levels of glycine, glutamine, glutamic acid, fumaric acid, and citric acid were increased in the hypothalamus of HFD + BGEH mice.

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the metabolic differences induced by black ginseng in conditions of obesity by conducting metabolic profiling of samples from the serum, liver, and hypothalamus using GC-MS.
Question_6.Question: Which metabolites were increased in the hypothalamus of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_6.Source: Among them, all except GABA were detected at higher concentrations in the HFD + BGEH group than in the HFD group.

Question_7.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the obesity-preventing effect of black ginseng in the serum, liver, and hypothalamus of mice on a high-fat diet using metabolomic techniques.
Question_7.Question: What was the main finding regarding oxidative stress-related metabolites in the liver of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_7.D: Decreased decanoic acid and myristic acid
Question_7.Source: In the liver of the HFD + BGEH mice, the level of 5-oxoproline—known as an oxidative stress-relief biomarker—was elevated.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the metabolic differences induced by black ginseng in conditions of obesity by conducting metabolic profiling of samples from the serum, liver, and hypothalamus using GC-MS.
Question_8.Question: Which metabolites were decreased in the liver of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_8.B: Decanoic acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid
Question_8.Source: A total of 26 metabolites were statistically significant in the liver of the HFD + BGEH mice, comprising 13 lipids, including decanoic acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid.

Question_9.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the obesity-preventing effect of black ginseng in the serum, liver, and hypothalamus of mice on a high-fat diet using metabolomic techniques.
Question_9.Question: What was the main finding regarding neurotransmission-related metabolites in the hypothalamus of mice fed an HFD?
Question_9.B: Increased glutamic acid and fumaric acid
Question_9.Source: In the hypothalamus of mice fed an HFD, glutamine, glycine, glutamic acid, and 4-aminobutyric acid (GABA) involved in neurotransmission were markedly changed.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the metabolic differences induced by black ginseng in conditions of obesity by conducting metabolic profiling of samples from the serum, liver, and hypothalamus using GC-MS.
Question_10.Question: Which metabolites were identified as important contributors in the serum of mice fed an HFD with BGEH?
Question_10.B: Decanoic acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid
Question_10.Source: Specific changes in serum metabolites resulting from obesity-preventing effects of BGE were observed in lipid and amino acids metabolism.
